Problem: Suppose languages $L$ and $M$ are recognized by DFA with $m$ and $n$ states, respectively. Give as small a bound as possible on the number of states required to recognize $L \cap M$.

Trivially, $mn$ is an upper bound if we follow the standard construction of cartesian products.

However, Han & Salomaa [1] show that the tightest achievable bound is in fact $mn - 3(m+n) + 12$ states, being both necessary sufficient. They do so by regarding the set of states as an $m \times n$ matrix, and eliminating the states which are identical and thus unnecessary.

1: State Complexity of Union and Intersection of Finite Languages, ยง 4 and 5
Yo-Sub Han and Kai Salomaa
https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/dbf6/bc1e61e59f3afd7b4cd61ae560b4a75f38fa.pdf
